description:
Note that they only take cash. 

Ordered the General Tso chicken. It was hands down the best version of it I've ever eaten. So good that I came back a week later and got it again.
author: Al L.

description:
nice boss and nice food.

best chinese food in SFO. at least Best Street side style one.
author: Peter L.

description: I chose this place based on the reviews and we were staying at the Hilton Financial District. We walked in around 730p and the place was not that busy. And it is small. A word of advice... Don't let that deter you. This place has THE BEST FOOD. I am not joking. We saw the reviews on the General Tso's chicken so we decided to order that. Wow... If you are close to this place you can't go wrong. Go there and eat. It is worth it.
author: Richard R.

description: I went with a friend and we ordered two entrees, potstickers and soup. The soup was pretty good (hot and sour) and was spicy without needing to add much which was nice. The potstickers were good. We tried the beef with a garlic ginger sauce. I enjoyed it but the sauce came on the side which just felt weird to me. The orange chicken however was the best I've ever had and I will definitely be back for it soon. It was even good leftover. The employees were also sweet and helpful. Overall it was a great experience!
author: Sable B.

description:
My friends and I are always looking around for some hole-in-the-wall, hearty Chinese food in the city and through my friend's recommendation, I came here to eat and it was everything I wanted and more! First off, this establishment is cash only and it's a bit older, so don't expect fancy eats or those hipster joint feels.

I first came here with a friend and ordered three dishes to share between the two of us. We ordered the twice cooked pork, orange beef, and chicken chow mein. Wow, the flavors were spot on and it came out pretty quickly too! Did we finish it? Yes we did. More so my friend did and his stomach hurt the whole evening after. But that didn't stop us from coming back again but with more our friends. 

The next time we came back with three more of our friends and we ordered the general Tsao, twice cooked pork, orange beef, Hunan shrimp, and Hunan beef! It tasted just as delicious as before and a lot of us were saying, thank goodness they add vegetables in their dishes so it makes us feel like it's a bit more healthier than just eating the meat. The Hunan shrimp wasn't all that great, but the General Tsao was just the right balance between meat and the fried coating. It was sweet but also had a little kick to it. MUST ORDER. As well as the twice cooked pork (but that's just my favorite dish = biased).
author: Ada C.

description: This is a cash only restaurant! Visited this place when the family was in town for vacay, and we didn't know what to expect because there was nobody inside eating when we went. The staff was a little odd but friendly. The food turned out to be absolutely delicious. The fried rice was buttery and incredible. We all tried something new and everything was excellent. I would recommend checking this place out while in the city of you're looking for really great Chinese food. By the way, my little sister are all of her orange chicken which never happens at any restaurant. She's typically a picky eater but gobbled this food down!!
author: Rhianna M.

description:
I ordered Chicken with String Beans ($8.25?) and a large Hot and Sour Soup ($6.45?). My friend ordered the Twice Cooked Pork ($8.75?).

We decided to go to this restaurant because of the high Yelp ratings. However, I think this place deserves 2 to 2.5 stars. 

We came in at around 6:00 pm on a Friday night. We saw two other people sitting near us, but most of the time, we were the only people seated. When we got our menus, I noticed a pen was used to write new prices on top of the old prices. It was hard to tell how much our food costed. It was worse when we received our receipt. The receipt was in Chinese and we could not see the price of each individual item. We were only given one lump sum total. 

There was no way of knowing if our food would include rice. Rice was not listed anywhere on the menu. When I asked the waitress, she said I was given three options that was not on the menu:
1. Half a plate of rice, half the amount of Chicken with String Beans
2. The full amount of Chicken with String Beans
3. The full amount of Chicken with String Beans and a side of rice
I assumed the third option would mean we would have to pay for an extra side of rice. I ended up choosing the first option. 

Now for the food... it was just average.
Chicken with String Beans: There was barely any sauce, but tons of oil in this dish. The dish also included garlic pieces and sliced carrots. The carrots and green beans were a bit hard and crunchy. They tasted fine to me but compared to other Chinese restaurants, I would consider them to be a little undercooked. The chicken just tasted average and a bit plain. 

Hot and Sour Soup: This large soup included bamboo shoots, thin egg whites, small tofu slices, and fungi. Usually when I drink hot and sour soup, I would have to drink a lot of water. However, it was not really spicy even though I could see tons of little red pepper pieces. It was big enough to serve two people. 

Twice Cooked Pork: My friend tried to add chili sauce that was on the table to the pork because his dish wasn't spicy enough. He thought the chili sauce had a weird sour taste to it. He liked the cabbage in this dish though. The meat to vegetable (cabbage, broccoli, carrots, onions) ratio was really low. 

There were no signs on the walls or near the entrance that said this place was cash only. Luckily, we had cash with us. 

The waitress did not check up on us and we had to call her over for our bill. The two people who were sitting near us were going to pay for their meal. I noticed the waitress just stood next to them the whole time and waited until they paid after they were done eating. It was a bit awkward and I was concerned she was going to wait at our table the whole time after we finished our meals. When it came time to pay the bill, however, she ended up just setting the check on our table and left. We had to go up to the counter to pay. Furthermore, the waitress never asked us if we wanted water or tea. I think it is assumed you have to ask her for it. 

I don't think I will be coming back in the near future.
author: Kristina M.

description:
My friend and I live in the area and decided to stop by at Yan's after seeing the good reviews on Yelp. We were a little nervous when we walked in because there were no customers inside but decided to give it a try anyways. I'm really glad we did because the food is great! 

We particularly love the orange chicken, beef broccoli, and chicken chow mein. 

The owners are so nice and make the food fresh for you. Please note that it is cash only. 

Highly recommend going here for Chinese food/ takeout!
author: C S.

description: Delicious chicken and vegetables with fried rice!! About $10!! Affordable and good food. Also comes with appetizer
author: Cezanne B.

description: I had the orange tofu and egg fu young which were all right. They have cheap lunch specials and it is a bare bones spot...you just go here for the food. Was super slow when I was there, looked like they only had 1 chef.
author: Sunil R.

description:
This place better have good food because everything about it sucks so far....
And yes...the food was amazing!!
author: D.J. L.

description: I had the kung pao chicken and it was delicious! My husband had the general Taos chicken. It was delicious. Very spicy which he likes.
author: Stacey H.

description:
We found this place on Yelp and thought we'd give it a try. It is a tiny little place and does not look like much to look at but WOW the food is good. So much flavor and so well cooked. I had the chicken ginger garlic and it was amazing. The vegetables were cooked perfectly where they still had a little crunch. The seasoning was packed full of flavor. 
My wife had an eggplant dish that was also delicious. All the meals were so pretty too. 
My teenage sons had the kung pao chicken and the salt and pepper chicken and raved about them although I didn't taste them so I can't vouch for those. 
I can't recommend this place more. Don't pass it up by its looks. You will miss an amazing meal. The owners are very nice people too.
author: Sherwin D.

description:
Alright place a bit hit or miss tho. I got the general tso lunch combo which came with rice and choice of spring rolls, dumplings, or deep fried dumplings of which I selected the fried dumplings. The service was meh lukewarm water, they brought my food to the wrong table, and had to wait around for the check.

The fried dumplings were bomb and easily the highlight of the meal. They deep fry them in batter instead of your standard potstickers. The general tsos chciken itself was good but average and came with sliced jalapenos and sliced carrots which wernt cooked and were rock hard. I guess I cant complain for 10 bucks out the door but cmon.
author: Sean G.

description:
I'm really disappointed with you, Yelp. Yan's kitchen got 4 stars and I was really excited to try a new chinese spot close to my house, but it did not satisfy the cravings. The food lacked flavor and the meats were very chewy, thick and dry. For two girls, we ordered the chicken chow mein, beef with tofu and general tsao's chicken.

Chicken chow mein: very americanized, it was spaghetti noodles with very little sauce and the chicken was extremely dry. I did like that they gave generous vegetables like carrots and broccoli, but it tasted like eating we were just eating chicken with plain spaghetti

Beef with tofu: this is normally my favorite thing to order so i was super excited to order this when I saw it on the menu, but boy... I was very very disappointed. It wasn't the right type of beef, it was thick and large pieces that were extremely chewy - pass

General tsao's chicken: this was the only redeeming part of the meal, I mean how could you messed up chicken that was battered and fried right? Thankfully, their sauce tasted alright and they had chili peppers to add some kick. It wasn't the best dish I've had, but it made the meal better - otherwise I would have been very angry.

In conclusion, save yourself some money and go to chinatown for some authentic chinese food please. The meal was very cheap in comparison to a lot of other fidi places, but ultimately not worth the pocket money or calories.
author: Anh Thu P.

description: I ordered the combination chow mein, and it was awful. Instead of chow mein noodles, they used over-boiled spaghetti, so it just tasted like old cabbage flavored pasta. The few meats they added were very low quality. I would recommend avoiding this restaurant and buying Chinese food elsewhere. Note: Yan's accepts cash only (tax evasion).
author: Jessica T.

description: Good spot. I go for the lunch specials they try their best to modify the meals if need be. Cash only though
author: Juan T.

description:
A Diamond in the Rough

I came in around 5:30p on a Thursday for dinner and the restaurant was mostly full with only one table available. 

I ordered the Family Dinner for 2 to share and really enjoyed the flavors, texture, and aroma of the dishes. 

Overall

This place is a hole in the wall that delivers in flavor. I was only visiting the San Francisco area for a week but I never once regretted eating here. 

Looking forward to coming back on my next trip to the bay.
author: Nicholas B.

description: Came last night. Amazing place . great food. Satifactiing100% . We were so hurry. Long day for us.walking.traffic. but once we found this place. My joy. Came back . full of happiness in my mouth and belly..Great Food
author: Maria L.

description: Not as good as I would have hope for. I order three different dishes and they all weren't even close to tasty. Will not come back.
author: Mufasa O.

description:
Food was alright, purchased the Kung Pao tofu but it was extremely salty. On the other hand, the spring rolls are what deterred me from a lower rating because I actually really enjoyed them. My friend also ordered vegetable chow mien and enjoyed that. 
Unfortunately the device wasn't all that, ordered water and never got them nor did they ever check in on us. I probably won't come back if not for a small order of spring rolls.
author: Divine V.

description: Just ate here with some friends and the food was way below par. I was spitting food back into my napkin. We had three dishes and each disappointed. Meat was gritty and sinewy, the fried rice was skimpy and bland, and everything tasted the same- salty and indistinguishable taste. It was one of the worst Chinese food I ever had. The older couple who run the place are nice folks and I do not want to disparage their restaurant but for the $10 a dish price I have to warn you, Chinatown as a whole is not the place to experience good quality Chinese food these days.
author: Skyler A.

description:
If you come here, looking at yelp to see what to order here will definitely help!!! I highly highly recommend the Orange Chicken, Fried Rice, Mongolian Beef, and Shrimp & Vegetables. 

The people working at the restaurant are very friendly, attentive, and diligent. We walked in as a party of 20, and they seated us right away and made room for us. If you order the dishes I recommend, you won't be sorry!!! Definitely coming back here when I'm back in town! Thanks Yan's Kitchen for making our tummy full and happy!
author: Bianca M.

description:
I'm actually not sure how this place has such high reviews as it was Mediocre, at best, and actually more of a let down. Being here for only a couple evenings, I feel like we wasted an evening for fried chicken Chinese food. Per some other Review, I ordered the General Tso's Chicken (2) And we also got the Orange Chicken (3). They are pretty much the same thing but the Tso has a few Jalapeños in there and a little Sesame Seeds sprinkled on, that's it!!  Fried, with too much breading for sure. And rice doesn't come with it, so add another $5 for 2. Also, as noted, cash only. 

Again, I'm not sure how or why this place has such high praise but I know I'll never be back and I suggest you skip it too!!
author: Gordo C.

description:
No Chinese should ever try this place.  Unless you are in a pinch and need to get over a meal without thinking foods.  Then, you won't be reading this.

I got the lunch special, since there is nothing Hunan or dishes that require real cooking skills.  The prawns and tofu were in this overly salty sauce over a slightly stale rice.  I wolf'ed it down so that I won't be hungry anymore and just walked out.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: Delicious food and great customer service. My eleven year old son said it was the best Chinese food he had ever eaten. It was definitely delicious. I wish I lived in San Francisco so I could go there regularly.
author: Timothy S.

description:
Great food, good price. Lunch specials are good, plenty of food, and at a great price. There does appear to be only one chef, so I would not come here during peak times. We came at about 2pm- the food came out relatively quickly and was obviously fresh. Good option if you are in Chinatown, somewhat out of the way from the real touristy shops and restaurants but not difficult to find, right next to the TransAmerica pyramid. CASH ONLY, but there is an ATM close by if needed. Staff were really friendly and appear to be a husband-wife team.

One note, the restaurant is small, old (but clean), and somewhat dark. Just know this before you go, not your typical restaurant atmosphere.
author: Thomas P.

description: This is the best place for the price. General Tso's Chicken was melt in your mouth! Chow Mein was delicious as well and lunch special includes egg roll. Seriously the BEST Chinese food at this price level in SF!
author: Mel B.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night around 6:30 because my favorite cheap Chinese food restaurant was closed for renovations. When le bf and I came in, there was only 1 other person sitting inside. We had Yelped looking for Chinese food, and because of the price, and the fact that it was a hole in the wall, we were both up for it. 

After studying the menu and looking at what people recommended on Yelp, we decided to get:
1. Salt and pepper fried fish special with white rice and fried dumplings
2. Tofu and green bean special with white rice and fried dumplings
3. General Tso's chicken special with white rice and egg rolls.
4. Large hot and sour soup.

The portions were pretty big. Le bf and I ended up taking half of the bowl of hot and sour soup home along with basically the whole portion of General Tso's chicken and some fried dumplings. 

We both added more vinegar to the hot and sour soup because we didn't think it was sour enough, it wasn't too spicy either (which I liked because I'm a total wuss when it comes to spice). The fried egg rolls were really small and thin, packed with veggies only. The fried dumplings were literally dumplings, that were battered, and then fried. I have never eaten fried dumplings in that way. Le bf really enjoyed them and you could tell they were homemade. 

My favorite dish of the night was the tofu and green bean special. There were plenty of beans and tofu. The flavors really came together and the beans weren't soggy, they still had a crunch to them, which I enjoy. 

The fried fish came out hot and somewhat crispy. I just wish that the chef would have fried the fish for longer so that the batter was crunchier. The fish was extremely tender, which is a good thing. 

Le bf ordered his General Tso's chicken. I think he thought it was good, definitely not the best, but not the worst either. I think that the batter on the chicken could have been crispier. 

Overall, the price was reasonable and the food tasted good. Our whole entire dinner was only around $34 and we had enough leftover for another meal or 2. It is definitely a hole in the wall run by a nice husband and wife team. This place is also very vegetarian friendly. By the time we left, the restaurant was about 85% full. I think we will be back.

Pro tip: This place is cash only.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
I just cannot give this place 3 stars. I don't even know how it got 4 stars.

I came in during lunch. Americanized Chinese food btw. I noticed that this was going to take a while because there's only 1 cook and 1 waitress. But seeing as it's a mom and pop place I'll give it a pass. Our food took around 20 mins. Water and tea are served upon request. The fried dumpling that came with the lunch special wasn't bad. Only thing is the dumpling skin was pretty soggy.

For entree, I got the chicken with tofu over rice. Portion size was ok. It had chicken, tofu, broccoli, and carrots. First bite, SUPER SALTY. I'm a person who likes salty food but this was just too much. The broccoli and chicken were super salty as it soaked up a lot of the sauce. The tofu was bearable. The carrots were dry looking too. I had some leftovers so I took it back to work to eat later in the day; I don't waste food. Later on, I ate about 2 bites of my leftover and came a massive headache. My friend told me it's probably MSG overdose. I will have to agree. I still have said headache as I type this. 

My friend that went with me claimed her noodles were super salty and greasy which gave her an upset stomach. Another friend said her salt and pepper chicken was good and tender. I don't know what to believe but I'm not coming back.
author: Benita M.

description:
Authentic Chinese food. Humble setting and very nice owners. We had the general tsao, Kung pao, chicken chowmein and chicken fried rice. All were very tasty. They only use white meat for their chicken dishes which is a plus. 

Cons:
It was a bit cold inside. 

Pros:
Restrooms available.
Low prices.
Good portions.
author: Érica M.

description:
Regardless of my rating, I would come back here again. The food was alright, but it's fresh and plentiful. I came here around lunchtime on a weekday. The line wasn't too bad. Enough to make me realize that I should have called ahead to order. I satisfied my craving of mapo tofu with white rice. Luckily I knew from my fellow Yelpers that this place is cash only. 

The little carrots and peas that look like they came from a bag of frozen vegetables from Safeway weren't my favorite part, but I liked how sufficiently spicy the dish was. Again, it was a good sized portion. The rice was on the drier side (the way I like it) and the whole process from ordering to eating was quick. It's Chinese fast food without being Panda Express!
author: Stefanie C.

description: Had General Tso's for lunch... it was phenomenal.  We had House of Nanking last night and we both agreed that this place was much better.  Little hole in the wall, family run restaurant.  $25 for 2 General Tso's and 2 sodas.  Small spot, great service, great food.  Can't ask for much better.
author: Chaz D.

description: Nice little Chinese place at the edge of Chinatown. The food is ok, not great but definitely not bad and a little pricey for what you get and they only accept cash. I came in late and the place was empty, but they still didn't let me sit wherever I wanted. Maybe they thought a ton of people will suddenly come in? it was still empty when I left... Anyway, a nice place for a quick Chinese bite - nothing special but also not bad.
author: Gil S.

description:
Pretty good Chinese food at a decent price.

I ordered the General Tsao's chicken lunch special with rice and a deep-fried dumpling.  The flavor of the chicken was okay, but it tasted like it was fried a little too long.  The jalapeños added a nice kick.  The rice was also good but was a little lumpy.

The woman who took my order was very nice and there was not problem finding a table on a Monday.
author: Bob F.

description: Good food great price definitely coming back to this place. I have had a lot of Chinese food in California, Nevada, Arizona, and Utah and I have to say this is one of the best places I have eaten at. I would recommend this place to all my friends and family.
author: Keith A.

description: Great little place for a quick meal. Great value. Yummy food, family friendly. If I lived here in San Francisco, I'd visit all of the time.
author: Melissa M.

description: Food was great and relatively cheap. I really liked the old lady who cooked and served the food. She was very nice and delightful. The restroom was pretty small though.
author: Sydney X.

description: This place may not look like much from the outside, but it's amazing!!!! It's a little mom and pop type restaurant, the food is authentic Chinese food! My boyfriend and I both got the General tso chicken, so delicious!! I would come back here in a heartbeat.
author: Anne Marie A.

description:
Stern in appearance and face in stoic contemplation, I stared as the masses yearned for my critique. Unbeknownst to them, there was a vulnerable tell to my shrouded deliberation. My hand gave way to the idyllic thoughts of a brave Chinese chef deep frying chicken in the name of his superior, General Tso. Immediately my mind was enveloped of thoughts of the food critic from Ratatouille.

I would love to try other dishes here, but every time I come here I always order the General Tso's chicken. It is absolutely impeccable. The chefs themselves were trained by General Tso. The only way to describe the chicken is in layers. There is quite a bit of intricacy in how it's crafted. The outer layer is a delicious soft crunch, and as your teeth begin to penetrate this outer layer, they're met with a slightly harder crunch. It's quite subtle, but this is what makes their chicken so phenomenal. The precise reason is that it builds up an expectation, a familiar expectation from eating so much fried chicken, but instead of fulfilling that expectation, it comes at you like an M.Night Shyamalan twist. The twist is that slightly harder crunch. Normally you'd think after breaking through the first outer layer it would get softer, but nope. It was a minute increase in density that bypassed my expectations. 

Beyond the delicious and bewildering coating, the sauce was delicious but not overpowering, and the meat was incredibly tender and juicy. Their General Tso's Chicken is a paragon.
author: Ankur K.

description: Cheap, good for what you pay for. Sweet lady that was on top of it. Mongolian beef & General Tso chicken decent.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Oh man, I don't know. We came to Yan's kitchen and it appeared to be a sweet mom and pop style place. 

I hate writing this but they had so many dirty dishes piled up and it was empty besides my partner and I. I couldn't tell if they had picked up a clean pot for our dishes and once we got our food the noodles and chicken were swimming in oil. I do not exaggerate - I had to take bites without looking, hoping that it wasn't as bad as I thought. Also, they only take cash. I wish there were signs by the door or somewhere else besides the small one by the register so that we could've gone elsewhere. My husband had to walk all over to find an ATM while I sat there in silence enduring the stinging pain coming from my stomach. Which, by the way, we got sick pretty soon after we left Yan's kitchen. 

So disappointing.
author: Abby M.

description: Great inexpensive, family run, "hole in the wall" Americanized Chinese food. Everything was clean, service was friendly and quick, and the food was quick. The battered and fried dumplings were unique and very good as other yelpers have noted. The twice cooked pork was excellent but the broccoli chicken just ok. They offer anchor Steam beer which works well with Chinese.
author: Chris V.

description: Found this restaurant on yelp and it was pretty close to my hotel so I thought I'd give it a try. There was nobody in the restaurant when I got there around 4-4:30 so I wasn't sure if they were open. I ordered the won ton soup and general tso's chicken with vegetable rolls. The soup was pretty flavorful and the dumplings cooked to perfection. I also enjoyed the vegetable egg rolls. I am conflicted about the general tso's chicken. The breading reminded me of funnel cake breading and had a similar taste. The sauce for the chicken was pretty good and not at all spicy. I'm just visiting the city, but I probably would not visit this restaurant again.
author: Nicki S.

description:
Yan's Kitchen is the best Chinese place in San Francisco!

It is run by the nicest people ever and the food is delicious!
author: Andrew R.

description: Cheap, quick, and tasty. I especially like their fish dishes, which come with good portions and the fish is not breaded heavily like in other Chinese restaurants in the area. And the service is great! Definitely my go-to Chinese place in the neighborhood.
author: Carl W.

description: Service isn't friendly nor decor something to write about, but the food is so good it makes up for the rest.
author: Cristobal P.

description: This is a hidden jem, there prawns are amazing the fried dumplings are 10 stars and the fried rice and chow main are alright. Amazing spot
author: Kayla S.

description: The food was good, just wished there was a little more variety. Place was also small but you can taste the authentic taste.
author: Larry L.

description: This is my go-to for Chinese food when I'm in the Financial District! My best friend showed me this place a few years back, and her boyfriend showed it to her, he has been going here for many years. Great prices, but remember cash! The best dish there is the Salt and Pepper Chicken. I had never tried this before, so was hesitant when my friends said I had to order it! But do it, you won't regret it. Pure AMAZINGNESS. :)
author: Bella C.

description: this place is amazing they have the best  Chinese  food I ever tasted! They treat you like family an are very nice.
author: Rosa V.

description:
My company moved into the area recently and we are still exploring our lunch options, so we thought we would try Yan's. This is definitely a good bang for your buck lunch spot if you want Americanized Chinese food. I'll likely be back for takeout, but I don't think it will make the my usual lunch rotation. Overall a 3.5 from me.

*this place is cash only

Food: 3.5
Lunch specials give you a choice of white rice or fried rice (+$1.00), and an order of steamed dumplings, fried dumplings, or fried eggrolls.
I ordered the orange chicken. It was decent, but nothing to write home about. It seemed like it was fried for a little too long. 3
My coworkers ordered the general tso's chicken, mongolian beef, and broccoli chicken. Their ratings for the food were 4, 4, and 3 respectively. So overall pretty good.

Service: 5
The place was empty (~11:50am On a Wednesday) so our group of 5 sat down immediately. Service was really quick as expected. No complaints.

Ambience: 3
This place is fairly small, but had tables that could seat about 6 people. Decor is what you would expect for a hole in the wall kind of place like this. It never filled up for lunch so it stayed pretty quiet.
author: Ryan J.

description: A small mom and pop shop that always offers fresh and tasty Chinese cuisine.  Found this place a few years back and always stop in when we're in the mood for some good food.
author: Auggie M.

description: Do not believe the high reviews. This restaurant was terrible. Our table ordered two noodle dishes: the chicken noodle soup and the vegetable chow mein.  The noodles were not Asian noodles but spaghetti noodles. The chow mein was served with greasy, undercooked vegetables. The chicken soup was ok and the won ton soup was probably the best meal served.  I am fine with a hole in the wall that is a little dusty and the food is amazing. This place was grimy with food that lacked in flavor.
author: Meme B.

description:
Cheap basic Chinese American food.  General Tsiu shrimp breeding fell apart with touch of chop stick.

Dumplings are bland.
Place smells like grease when you enter.
author: David H.

description: This place has great dumplings, everything else was just so/so. The women who was working seemed like she was very unhappy to be serving me. Not the best experience. I wasnt a fan of the hot and sour soup. The hot chili that they have sitting on the tables tasted awful, it seriously tasted expired!! The hot and sour soup clearly had this chili in it and the flavor was so strong I couldn't eat it. Definitely wont be returning.
author: Kelli N.

description: Dear God, I haven't had Chicken Broccoli that good EVER!  Don't be fooled by the unassuming looks of this place.  I will gladly eat here again the next time I visit San Fran.  Just the kind of diamond in the rough that do it old school and folks like me love it!
author: Heath W.

description:
This place made my day. After exploring the city by foot the food here hit the spot! I ordered General Tso's and the food was perfection!  Rice was Lightner hearty, the chicken was tender and the batter thin with just the right amount of sauce. Even though the sauce was generous the batter remained crispy. The fresh jalapeño wad to die for and added just the right amount of heat. So impressed with the food. 

You may wonder why 4 stars then? The place struggles with cleanliness in the dining area. The waitress was disgruntled, did not bring water, and I had to wait 30 minutes for my order to be taken. Decided to walk up and pay, I would have been late to my flight otherwise! Cleanliness and some costumer service improvements would make this place a 5 star. 

Having said that, I would still go back and perhaps get some takeout!
author: Blanka A.

description: The pork fried rice and lemon chicken were yummy yummy to my kiddos tummy.  Be back for more
author: Dyniece A.

description: Place was good for a quick bite! People are nice and the food was about average. BBq Pork FR, Chicken w/Broc, Spring Rolls...all on par with most fast food Chinese!  Enjoy.
author: Ben Y.

description:
The good reviews here are to be believed, indeed. I didn't expect too much and got back amazing value for my dollar. This was one of the best Chinese food meals I've ever had. 
According to one family member I spoke to, Yan's has been here for 25 years. So, support local business in SF.
author: Patrick L.

description: Took absurdly long to serve us. Like 25 minutes before she even took out order, damn near an hour before we got our food. people that came after us were served and done with their food before we even got our appetizers.
author: Edward B.

description: Wow we came to San Francisco fromTucson Az for our 20 year anniversary and had one chance to eat Chinese food in Chinatown. The food was so good. We we're very iffy because the outside looked a little worn. I'll change that to broken in. We enjoyed every bite and there was no up charge for the view like every where else in SF.
author: Mark I.

description:
Weary after slogging through a rainy Chinatown, finding Yan's outside of bustling Chinatown was a nice surprise (ok, not really a surprise, we found it on Yelp!).  As we had done so far at other restaurants, we decided to pick through the menu to try a few things - first the dumplings (very good, filled with meat) then an order of orange chicken (included a massive scoop of steamed rice).  

I picked a nice cold Tsing Tao to wash down the snacks, which was the perfect touch for an early afternoon treat.
author: Patrick K.

description:
$10 for standard Chinese takeout bok choy chicken? No way! Culinary profiteering at Yans. 

The dish was good. Bok Choy was soft and well seasoned. The chicken was tender but its mouthfeel was uninteresting. Rice nicely soaked up the seasonings and was well executed.
author: Jack M.

description: This place is delicious!!! Cooked fresh and so good! Close walk from the financial district and China town! Would recommend to anyone.
author: Kelli L.

description:
Perfect home cooked type of meal in a nice homey environment. Husband cooks wife serves with a smile that can light up the space ship! I've been eating here for a while, every time I craved a home cooking.

General Tso chicken -5/5
Chicken in ginger garlic sauce - 5/5
Pot stickers - 5/5

This place is a must try!
author: Vikas J.

description:
I ordered the salt n pepper fish with white rice and 2x egg rolls. The fish was good but a tad too oily for me and the egg rolls were delicious!

I'm definitely interested to try their other dishes.
author: Alice X.

description: The food was great. The fried dumplings were easily the best I've ever had. The service was quick and the bathroom was clean. Definitely recommend- get the fried dumplings !
author: Kenzie M.

description: Was drawn to try this place by reviews of other fellow Yelpers and we weren't too disappointed. We ordered lunch plates: curry chicken, chicken with broccoli and a vegetable chow mein a la carte. The curry was on point. Right amount of curry flavor and vegetables and chicken breast pieces. It was delicious. The chicken with broccoli was good but not great. The lunch plates come with 2 vegetable egg rolls. The egg rolls were TOO GREASY! The chow mein was TOO GREASY too! The noodles looked and tasted like spaghetti noodles and he sauce was tasty but not enough soy sauce. The tea is in bulk which is better then a teabag but served in a small plastic water glass instead of a teapot and tea cups which was a let down. You will need extra napkins to drain the oil from the egg rolls. We had to keep asking the waitress for extra napkins as there are none on the table and We needed some extra ones to wipe our mouths and greasy fingers. The waitress was nice but skimpy with the napkins because we asked 2 times for some and each time we only got one. We were a party of 3. Other than that, the food was better then other places we've been to lately.  We would return if we were in the area.
author: Review L.

description:
Yan's Kitchen is my favorite happy hour go-to restaurant near where I work. Note that they only accept cash here! Their happy hour is from Mondays through Fridays 11-3pm, and it starts from $7.35 which includes steamed rice with either steamed or fried dumplings.

I ordered the salt and pepper chicken with fried dumplings and was not disappointed. The wait was a bit long (10 minutes), but that's because they were busy and only had one server and cook. I'm assuming that it's the husband and wife.

I took my order to go and thank goodness they have huge servings! The chicken was freshly cooked, and it had the right texture. It wasn't overcooked nor undercooked - it was perfect! The fried dumplings were great too!

Overall, I highly recommend checking this place out if you're looking for a restaurant that has happy hour and big portions.
author: Aj C.

description:
this place was great food - I was surprised because it doesnt look great
but nice friendly couple runnning the place and really good food. I had the hunan veggie rice plate which was great, nice sized portion and super cheap.
author: David G.

description: This is the purest mom and pop spot imaginable. There are only two staff -- mom handles all the service and pop does all the cooking. Mom is incredibly sweet and kind -- she is always happy to see me and knows my order by heart. If you come mid-afternoon when business is slow, you'll spot pop reading a newspaper at one of the tables or the both of them hosting friends. I actually don't care how good the food is -- I just want these people to be successful.
author: J S.

description: Tried this place last night and it was good. The only thing that sucked was cash only. But it is worth coming back to.
author: Dante C.

description:
1. Dirty nasty place.  Here's a tip... go the home depot and buy a box of Raid foggers.  Set off one night and get rid of all the nats and fruit flies that practically carried me away.

2.  Food:  M'eh... Generals Chicken... think not. Mostly the fried batter..where's the chicken?  Spice rack on table... get a rag and clean the bottles.

3.  Price:  Great price, you get what you pay for here.

4.  I'm an avid yelper before going out to a place... Yelp you let me down on this place, I can't believe the great reviews here after my experience.
author: Keith M.

description: I wouldn't go to another place in the city. Whenever I'm in the area I stop by Yan's. It's something about the people and the food here. My favorite in the city!!!
author: Dominic D.

description: Make me sick... this place honestly tastes okay, but who knows what you're eating. Would much rather eat at Panda Express. Even the water here is gross. DO NOT EAT HERE. It will ruin you're stomach. Like I said, it does taste good, but the chicken isn't chicken.
author: Vinnie S.

description:
This is one of those places, "don't judge a book by it's cover." Food was fantastic! Outside ignorable, only found this place through yelp reviews. Came here near closing time and no one was here, had seconds thought of going somewhere else but luckily didn't. 

The shrimp fried rice has that wok flavor you can't get at home, top notch! General Tsao's chicken was crispy and full of flavor but mostly batter. The mongolian beef was great with rice.

Great place to order from to-go.
author: Hui L.

description:
lol pretty much the most Americanized Chinese food I've had in recent memory. Is that a bad thing? No, not necessarily, as long as you know what to expect when you come in. They have a set of lunch specials from 11am-3pm that are all around $6.50, where you get a bowl of soup, your choice of dumplings or egg rolls, and your choice of one of roughly 15 American-Chinese entrees.

I ended up going with the Hunan chicken, upgrading my dumplings to XLB, though, in hindsight, I really should have just straight up ordered the orange chicken instead (I think the Asian in me was trying to resist that urge). That said, they do also have a regular menu, which I imagine has more traditionally Chinese dishes.

How was the food though? It was okay. The XLB weren't really like XLB at all: just giant dumplings wrapped XLB style, minus the soupy goodness. The Hunan chicken itself was chock full of flavor, but definitely came in on the too-salty side (catering to more American taste buds, I imagine). Still, given the pricing, I could see myself coming again if I were in the mood, in the way that some people do actually crave Panda Express on occasion.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - There's a single 2-3" step to get in to this smaller restaurant, but, once in, you'll find that the majority of the seating is accessible, save for the counter/kitchen seating.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so no comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
We stopped in late night around 9pm right before they closed. I make a quick selection off the specials menu and went with the bok choy wtih chicken for about $10. We ordered to go. 

The dish was thinly sliced grilled chicken squares, with steamed chopped bok choy atop white rice. The bok choy was good, cooked right and coated with chicken broth flavor. I liked how the chicken broth taste was present throughout the dish. The plate also came with 2 fried dumplings. These are'nt your typical fried dumplings,no. They are completely deep fried in hot oil until a golden crispy brown. They were pretty awesome.
author: Christopher M.

description: This place was recommended  by our landlord. Place is on a main street but was very dark and table was sticky. Price was reasonable.  They only accept cash. Large menu. Potsticker was overcooked but did not come with a sauce.best dish was the garlic chicken. Tried the general  tsao chicken. It was deep fried. It had a good flavor. The low me in was tasty but pork was mostly fat. We had back toy with garlic sauce but they forgot the gsrlic
author: Anthony K.

description: This is one of my fav Chinese place. I used go there a lot when I was working in the city. The old lady and gentleman are both no nice. They were taking my custom orders like changing seafood to meat..etc. my fav dishes are Mongolian beef and slt&papepr chicken/beef/pork whatever. Mongolian is so flavorful and thick. It might be a bit salty for some people, but ask them before order, they would be happy to adjust. Also, they are supportingly quick as they are only two operating the restaurant. You guys rock!
author: Michael K.

description: Not very good. Food is ok but quality is not what we were expecting. We ordered Mongolian beef and it didn't look like beef.
author: Claudia F.

description:
Discovered this place kinda on accident while strolling through Chinatown. 

The husband & wife team that runs Yan's Kitchen is truly a dynamic duo. You'll hardly see Yan glance up from his woks - leaving his wife, Mei, to (wo)man the front lines.

While the decor leaves a bit to be desired (think of it as an exercise in simplicity!), the food itself is filling, tasty, and best of all...affordable for any budget. 

Coming in the day after Bay To Breakers, the GF and I desperately needed some hangovers taken care of, and fast. To that end, Yan's did not disappoint. 

We ordered an order of Combination Chow Fun, some Hunan Beef and a side of Fried Rice. 

The Hunan Beef was well-seasoned and the vegetables retained their crunch very well. Also, the dish had just the right amount of heat - not too overwhelming, but a really subtle kick. 

The Chow Fun was also delicious; there's something about the quality and freshness of the meat/poultry/vegetables at Yan's that surpasses that of other Chinese places. Similarly, the portions served were surprisingly large, even by Chinese restaurant standards. 

In spite of the fact that we had come right in the middle of a busy lunch hour crowd, we were seated pretty quickly. To her credit, Mei was also very cheery in taking our order and making sure that we were well attended to. It was funny catching her and her husband having a quick laugh with one another after the restaurant cleared out; their teamwork is evident and very much admirable - they clearly have the formula for success down pat! 

Kudos to the duo at Yan's, not only for turning out such a high-quality product, but for showing that it's entirely possible to make a living doing what you love. I wish them nothing but continued success and prosperity!
author: Mark V.

description:
I had parked at the Portsmouth garage at Kearny and Washington because I knew we were going to be in San Fran for the better part of the day and I had planned on visiting Yan's Kitchen based on the many positive reviews on Yelp.  

It was basically around the block from where I had parked.  The place is exactly as how it was reviewed by many of the others here.  The place is dated and could use a make over but that's not what you have to worry about when you come to this place.  If you want ambiance go someplace else.  This place's strength is the food that the chef is pumping out all on his own.  

The place is really small.  We sat at a table for 6 because 2 other tables of 4 were not cleared from the previous customers.  The place only has maybe 8 to 10 tables?  The place is run by a couple and they are doing the best they can.  The female is taking orders and serving, clearing tables, cashing out while the male is pumping out all the dishes he can non stop.  

This is really a hard working couple and I knew that others had mentioned that the service may be a bit slow but until you go there for yourself you won't understand why.  The place is pretty busy and we saw couples, other tourists, locals come and go and you can see why locals would totally be enamored with this place.  Their food is amazing... period.

We were 3 adults and 1 child so I tried to order accordingly.  We ordered one bbq pork fried rice, combination chow mein, sesame beef and general tso chicken.  I saw many people say in their reviews that the General Tso's was the best they ever had so I was more than intrigued to try it myself.  

Well eventually the General Tso's came to the table and it was absolutely true.  This was the best General Tso's ever.  It has a nice tang while having a nice crispy light batter to it.  The batter is so light it's sublime and the sesame beef wasn't that different as well.  The chicken has some fresh slices of jalapeno peppers which was a nice sting to the dish.  I took them all because I was the only one who likes jalapeno's but overall the food was nothing short of the perfect.  My wife who is very particular about Chinese food said this was the best she ever had and I can't say I disagree with her.  

We only had 4 dishes but the meat dishes were the best I can say.  We sort of ran out of fried rice so I had ordered a steamed rice to go with our left overs which we were going to take out with us.  

I was very pleased that I went to Yan's because the reviews were absolutely spot on.  So 4 dishes and I had 2 beers and the bill was just over 40 bucks.  Talk about value as well...
author: Lambert P.

description: The reviews are right about one thing - the general tso is pretty good. However the orange chicken was soggy and falling apart. It was also a dark brown color not orange which was unnerving. The lemon chicken was alright but also very soggy which was just not appetizing. At least the chicken wasn't the usual diced, regurgitated looking stuff that most of these Chinese places serve. If anyone has tips for actual GOOD American/Hunan Chinese food in SF please message me! I have tried relentlessly to find a place. I think I'm just sticking to Panda Express for now.
author: Christopher J.

description:
I was in San Francisco briefly and decided to find a Chinese place with good reviews. I ordered my peraonal favorite General Tso chicken with fried rice, my wife had Mongolian Beef.  In short her food was great if it was just her they would probably have 4 stars easy.  Unfortunately my chicken was overcooked (downright crunchy).  When
I informed the lady helping us she informed me it's very popular and people like it that way.  Well I'm not people and I've had General Tso all over the country there's no justification for that.  I just paid the bill and left annoyed. Again my wife had no complaints so it's crap shoot if you're hungry, hopefully you have a meal more like my
wife's and not mine. Ps they don't accept credit cards, it's cash only.
author: Andre A.

description:
The food was reasonable but the woman working there tried to  short me on the change (5 dollars or so). When I accused her of it she immediately handed the money back to me, which is not something an innocent person would do, you'd expect there to be some hesitation. 

Bad ethics, don't support these people.
author: Adam W.

description: I love this place. The setting isn't fancy, the but couple who works here is so nice. The prices are good. I also find everything to be really fresh, and love all the veggies in the dishes I have ordered. My husband got Mongolian Beef an I got Broccoli Chicken (light on the sauce) and both were fantastic. I have been back a couple time and gotten the same order to go!
author: Laura T.

description:
DELICIOUS!!

AUTHENTIC!!

CHEAP!!

now go and enjoy! haha friendly staff i think owned by wife and husband very good food i never eat soup but theirs was reallyyyyy good first time i eaten a whole soup, orange chicken was good also very crisp too i enjoyed that
author: Oscar D.

description: The food was delicious. We had the hot and sour soup and a few dishes and everything was simply outstanding.
author: Tegan K.

description: We went today at about 4 and were the only ones there. The service was speedy and friendly. We both ordered from the specials list which came with dumplings or spring rolls. Get the fried dumplings. They were so good! After a long day of walking all over the city, this food was so good!
author: Brooke J.

description:
Not bad, but I'll try it again and possibly update my review.  The dining room is definitely outdated, but my review will have nothing to do with that.

The food is good, and it is fresh.  The vegetables seemed fresh and I was glad that there were not huge chunks of near raw green bell pepper.  Lots of Chinese spots include those and I don't care for it.  I also like my onions to be cooked a little more, but now that I know, I'll ask them to cook the onions a little longer next time.

My original motivation for going here was my hankering for some noodles.  I didn't do a very thorough eval of this spot for going, so I guess it is my fault that they didn't have crispy noodles (hong kong style).

The quality of the chicken was really good, not fatty, not dry, and it seemed like white meat.  This is key.  Some inexpensive Chinese places have horrible almost inedible meat, chewy, fatty, and nasty.  I was glad that this place was nothing like this.

The people working there (I'm guessing the owners) were nice and were not rude like you can sometimes get from other Chinese places.  They both seemed to be easy going and not in a rush (in a good way, not in a lazy way).

The prices were decent for what it was, but seemed a little on the high side for this type of food, but I guess it is closer to the fidi, so it probably has higher overhead.  $10 for a plate of chow mein after tax and tip.  The dish was also a little light on the noodles.

Give them a try, just don't go out of your way to come here if you are looking for a fancy or romantic meal.  If you want a quick lunch, it is worth a stop.
author: Ty C.

description:
We had American version 
Orange chicken fried rice and spring rolls 
It was absolutely awesome this place is s hidden gem I'm very satisfied with the cuisine highly recommend you stop in for a quick bite not much seating and place fills up fast 
Good luck teller
author: John W R.

description: Unbelievable rude service. The lady who I assume is the owner looked bothered when we walked in. She basically threw the menus at us and did not greet us. She never asked us what we wanted to drink. I had to ask her for cups for water and she tried to charge me for water cups. I told her to just give me the cups because I had a huge bottle of water with me. Finally when the food came it turned out to be greasy and oily americanized chinese food. I was not expecting that from a place with 4 star ratings. I am convinced the reason it has such high ratings is because of all the foreign people who come to Chinatown and think this is good chinese food. We ordered 3 plates off the menu that we all planned to share, but she only gave us 1 spoon and fork! Again I had to ask her for more plates and silverware so we wouldn't have to eat with our hands. Will NEVER be back and guess who did not get a tip?
author: Kev N.

description:
Hidden Gem that needs to be discovered by all...although I almost don't even want to tell people about it so it can remain a great secret! 

Uncle wanted to come here after he got off his flight from LA, a cousin of ours recommended Yan's so we went here. Walked up and it looked like my favorite kind of restaurant, a hole in the wall. Walked in and my uncle already knew what he wanted, General Tsos Shrimp, Combo fried rice no veggies, extra egg along with an order of veggie rolls. 

A couple of sake shots later the food arrived and my uncle and I were very pleased. It is great to see a Chinese food place still making FRESH food at a beyond reasonable price!  The bill was so surprising the lady joked with us and said she gave us 50% off! I will recommend this place to many of my friends and will definitely be returning on my own very soon. 

Yan's is the place to go!
author: Charles D.

description:
Cash only! I found that out the hard way. The beef and broccoli was pretty good. The fried rice was decent, but I asked for no peas or carrots (why would anyone put peas and carrots in rice? It's not a pot pie!) The fried pork dumplings were awful. I was expecting something like P.F. Chang's pan-fried dumplings. What I received was a gob of tempura batter wrapped around what may have once been a dumpling, with very little filling. A grease ball. I couldn't eat it. The egg-flower soup was bland and tasteless as well.

The entrees all tasted very similar to each other; high in sodium and overly dressed with soy sauce. It's your average Chinese food place, probably perfect for satisfying a craving for Chinese food after a night of binge drinking or some adult extra-curricular activities. Just stick to the classic dishes. You won't be expressing culinary wonderment at the chef's deft hand in creating explosive flavors, but you also won't be hurling in disgust (unless you order the dumplings) or experiencing disintery either. If you order the dumplings, you're on your own and I'll just say, "I told you so" right now.

Because I was pleased regarding their willingness to make my rice without the peas and carrots, (which tells me their food is made-to-order), the prices are unbelievably LOW (three of us had lunch specials consisting of appetizer, soup, entree, and rice for under $20 total) and the food was definitely better than Panda Express, I would order from here again in the midst of a craving for a quick Chinese food meal. 

Convenient walk from the finanical district of downtown SF.
author: Heather A.

description:
This place is a small mom and pop shop in Chinatown and it is pretty delicious! The restaurant was empty when we came in so no wait. 

Came with a group of friends and ordered General Tso chicken, orange chicken, broccoli beef, rice & chow mein. 

We were completely full! 
However I would not recommend the broccoli beef, it's a little on the salty side. 

Other than that everything was great, definitely recommend!
author: Stephany Z.

description:
I had a quick stay in San Francisco and was looking for a tasty lunch spot so I hit up Yan's Kitchen, which was right around the corner from my hotel room.

I started off with a small won ton soup. It certainly wasn't small. It had a tasty broth, a good dose of peas, carrots and other veggies, and 5 big won tons! My lunch platter came with 2 small spring rolls which were also delicious, and then the entree of General Gao's Chicken with rice. 

Yan left me very pleased with my meal, and I would definitely seek them out again for lunch near Chinatown.
author: Keith H.

description: This place is a hole in a wall. Not too great of an ambiance but the food was delicious for the value of your money considering everywhere in SF is way overpriced. We had salt and pepper shrimp, general tzu chicken, beef broccoli, seafood medley on sizzling place. Everything except for salt and pepper was tasty. The shrimp came in a small portion and without the head and shell in it which makes the salt and pepper shrimp dish. The couple were very accommodating and hard working.
author: Chiarra W.

description:
We were in Chinatown for the first time and wanted to find a good Chinese food place. I came across Yan's Kitchen via Yelp. The reviews were good and the pictures provided a good image of the food. 
As we arrived, we found a good parking spot.  The cook and the waitress were very humble people. Our order was promptly served and the taste of the food was amazing. The veggies were fresh and had good flavor.  We ordered from the lunch menu. 

My husband had the #19; which had a combination of chicken, beef and shrimp in Mongolian sauce with vegetables. 

I had the #3; house special/beef with vegetables. 

Both of our kids had the orange chicken lunch special. 

Each lunch special comes with your choice of rice and/or 2 dumplings/egg rolls. 

We all chose egg rolls. They were very crispy and had a fresh flavor to them.
author: Veronica O.

description:
Chow fun
Mongolian beef
Orange chicken
Fried dumplings
Shrimp egg foo young 

We're all so flavorful and authentic! Remember to bring cash and be patient the food takes time to leave the kitchen since they cook with fresh ingredients.
author: Jeanette N.

description: General Tso's chicken was average at best, soup scalding hot, didn't receive lunch special dumplings until I asked about them a few minutes after the entree arrived. Service slow, asked for a beverage twice but never received it.  Place became very hectic as the lunch hour progressed due to parade of to-go orderers that left the older lady working the register and the floor overwhelmed.
author: Andrew R.

description: I should have known it wasn't good when it was completely empty and the restaurants on either side were packed. Horribly bland, cold food, even worse service. The tall man that works there made me feel incredibly uncomfortable. With so many great choices in the neighborhood, I would never come back here.
author: Taylor S.

description: The food was so good. We ordered the general chicken...shrimp fried rice...and Mongolian beef. Fresh...and very tasty.
author: Kimberly O.

description:
Nice little place to get some quick and tasty Chinese food. They have a pretty standard menu, but the thing that stood out the most were the fried pork dumplings. So delicious! Super crunchy and perfectly fried on the outside, but just like a regular dumpling on the inside. Definitely a must try.

Don't forget it's cash only!
author: Jaymie S.

description:
Great little gem!  This is a little mom and pop shop which holds true to what counts most... a great tasting meal.  We had a great experience at dinner. The food was delicious and the service was as expected.

The decor is a bit dated and has that charming hole-in-the-wall kinda feel... which I think makes the experience that much better. We also notice a lot of "regulars" coming in for a meal.  We had the combination fried rice and chicken and vegetables. Both had great flavor, the food was fresh and perfectly cooked and very well priced. 

Enjoy!
author: Frank C.

description:
General Tso's chicken is amazing! Batter is all fresh light and crispy! Superb!

Ok embarrassing ending to my dinner time here. I go to pay my $15 for the Tso and fried rice and 2 Anchor Steams (amazing!) and they dont take credit card. So I ask where the ATM is and ask if they mind me heading up the street to get cash out and come back. I get to the ATM only to discover I had left my cash card back home on the East Coast and who remembers their PIN to their VISA. I go back to explain the situation. The wife is not there but the husband, the chef whom I had just praised for the best General Tso's chicken ever, I told. He graciously accepted the $5 dollars cash I had and said no worries! Wow is his wife ever going to kick his butt! Tomorrow I will head back with cash and a large tip.
author: Matt B.

description:
I came to this place tonight with a friend, got sat at a table for two and then proceeded to look at the menu. My friend really needed to use the restroom, so he got up to do that while I perused the menu. They had some good options and very reasonably priced. The decor wasn't much but sometimes those hole-in-the-wall type eateries have the best food.

I was all set to order when my friend came back, eyes wide, and told me that there are COCKROACHES hanging out on the bathroom wall in full view. It goes without saying that we refused to eat there. We politely told the server we were leaving because of what we saw and he had the nerve to charge my friend $2 for using the bathroom without ordering food. He paid and we left because we couldn't get out of that place fast enough but for any current and future patrons, be warned. This place clearly isn't up to code.
author: Mikal M.

description:
Decent, affordable Chinese food in a clean, above-average setting for a Chinatown-area restaurant. Helpings were plentiful, the taste was OK, and the two older folks here were *super* sweet and took care of me well (although, granted, I knew exactly what I wanted, could speak the language, and struck up a nice conversation with them).

Not gourmet, mind-blowing food by any means, but it gets the job done well, and, all of the above considered, I'll be generous and bump up what would otherwise be a 3-star "pass" rating to a 4-star "high pass" review. You could do far worse for your money in Chinatown.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Yan's makes your typical Americanized Chinese food--flavorful than most, but, like many Americanized Chinese restaurants, not the healthiest. It could be worse though.

I ordered the chicken with vegetables and fried dumplings, but they made a mistake on our take-out order (which took forever, btw)... My friend ended up getting someone else's entree instead of his, and worse, they forgot our fried dumplings! We were pretty upset, but were ultimately able to feed ourselves with the large portions anyway.
author: Kimberly Y.

description: Mediocre food. Don't touch the chilli condiment. It's suspiciously spoiled. Next time I'll go to Panda Express instead.
author: Putri I.

description:
***Cash Only, No MSG***

If you spend $13.00 at this restaurant and if you are still hungry, you have an issue.

Their lunch special costs only $6.45 and you will get a small bowl of soup (weekday only), 2 pieces of dumplings or spring rolls and the main dish with rice. Yan's Kitchen gets 5 starts in my "Cheap Chinese Eats" category.

Coming to this restaurant is like seeing the movie "Boyhood." Nothing spectacular or dramatic things occur but people find it heartwarming and soulful. 

This restaurant is located on the edge of Chinatown, just 1 block from Transamerica Pyramid. Clearly, Godzilla fell down just 2 blocks from this restaurant in the latest movie but Mr. Yan's has been passionately cooking for more than 20 years like nothing happened. 

Mr. Yan and his wife, Mei are some of the nicest people on earth. A lot of repeaters come back to this restaurant to enjoy the cheap but delicious food and to see their smiles. Every time I come to this restaurant, I feel like I were invited to a Chinese friend's house and their kitchen happened to be the size of a small restaurant. And the friend's parents cook the food for me. Even if you come here alone, they will be happy to welcome you. 
The decor may be dated but that's a charm and we, repeating customers don't care. 

The most popular dish here is "General Tso's Chicken" and it is really good. I also like to order "Salt and Pepper Fish", "Fried Rice" and any dish with broccoli because their broccoli is always cooked perfectly. If you order Shanghai Dumplings, you may find there is no soup in them. It may be affected by the unusual California drought. They still taste good! 

Sometimes, fine dining at Michelin-starred restaurants gets boring. We pay hundreds of dollars and get food with the sous-vide meat, the foam and the spherification. Although, the dishes may have chef's creative passion, some dishes have no soul at all. 

Here at Yan's Kitchen, every dish is soulful and served with love. 

If you are a lady and dumped by your boyfriend, come here even when you are in your sweat pants or in your pajamas and eat a lot. Mr.Yan and Mei's smiles and their food will comfort you.  
Most of all, their food will give you plenty of energy to slap your ex-boyfriend's cheeks super hard. 

Enjoy!
author: Manabu M.

description: Excited to see a cheap Chinese restaurant, but sad that the portion for the combination chow fun was small and also quite bland. I had to add a lot of sriracha for it to taste like anything. It was also pretty greasy, but that might just be the nature of the chow fun.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Yan's is a great little place right in between China Town and Little Italy run by Husband and wife. Food is pretty good and not weird like some places in China Town. Lol
Just make sure you take cash because it's "CASH ONLY".  Mr. and Mrs. Yan are very nice hard working people. General Tso Chicken and Orange Chicken taste delicious!
author: Eddie V.

description: Old school, dirty, hole in the wall, greasy Chinese food. Novelty to sit at the bar. Nothing distinctive, but strangely nostalgic. Lots of old single guys eating there.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Boy, do I miss great Chinese food.  We got the General Tso's and combination fried rice.  I could eat this every day!  And on top of it all, really inexpensive.

General Tso's, really crispy and not that overly sweet flop you oftentimes get.  Fried rice, really hit it.  I don't know what exactly it was, it was just right.

Next time I am in town I will certainly come back.  

Oh yeah, cash only.
author: Ann Beth C.

description:
I have to thank Yelp for this one. I searched Yelp for a Chinese restaurant and after reading a few reviews, we gave this place a try. 

We went at 3 PM on a Sunday afternoon.  The mom and pop owners were the only two in the restaurant.   

We ordered general tsos chicken, broccoli beef, combination house chow mein.  We ate everything. It was fantastic. I would have easily paid more money for this food.

Cash only. Don't forget. Great food at an even greater price.  Generals tsos was the best I've ever had, anywhere. 

Even though the health rating is very high on this place... The only thing keeping it from five stars is the fact it can use a good cleaning.

Their one highchair was from the 80s.  Awesome, metal folding highchair. I haven't seen one of those in 20+ years.
author: Heather P.

description:
While every other business in the area seems to be raising prices and offering more kale salads and blue bottle coffee than people know what to do with, Yan's is still serving up delicious and affordable meals for under $7. 

It's the only place I know of where the namesake of the business is actually making your food. Yan is a boss with the wok, turning out more dishes than the entire cast of Hell's Kitchen has all season. His wife Mei is incredibly sweet and handles the register and tables. Highlights include Mongolian and General Tso's chicken and each dish is served with a side, either dumplings or egg rolls. If you dine in, you'll get a cup of soup and hot tea as well. 

They are the real deal, an amazing couple who's been providing awesome food and great service for two decades. Do yourself a favor and read their full history under more info; you'll be glad you did.
author: Nick P.

description: Decent spot, lunch specials are super cheap. The general gaus chicken was pretty good. I haven't ordered it in about 20 years since I was in college. The hot and sour soup was very good. This is a decent spot, but nothing to write home about.
author: Jonah K.

description:
A hidden gem!

There's nothing better than a quick, freshly-cooked lunch under $9 in the city. Usually I pick up the 'Lunch Special' order: 2 spring rolls and Kung Pao shrimp with rice. The service is always friendly and welcoming.

Cash only, so bring your bills.
author: Kim T.

description:
I used to eat here a lot . Cheap and good quality . Woman and Man is very nice ! Small place but really good to have a quick lunch . Tasty enough . 

Thanks !
author: Jay M.

description: I went to Yan's Kitchen on a Tuesday evening with two friends visiting from out of town. It was very quiet, with just two customers sitting by the window. The server took our orders promptly, and we had them in under ten minutes: General Tso's chicken ($7.75), bok choy with shrimp and mushrooms ($7.75), and a side of white rice. Straightforward and flavorful, with fair portions (around 8oz chicken and 6oz shrimp), it was just what we expected. We left shortly after we finished; a quick, filling meal before spending the night out. If I ever had cash on me, I would return!
author: Brian C.

description:
This is a small restaurant run by what I assume is a husband and wife team. When we arrived, there was a large party going on that took up about half the restaurant. The other few tables hadn't been cleared, as the two people working were busy with the large party. They moved some things around to accommodate us and all was well. 

The prices were very reasonable, we paid under $30 for three people. The food was super fresh and had none of the "old oil" flavor that often is found in smaller Chinese restaurants. We had the lemon chicken - different than any lemon chicken I have had before, I would describe it as more mildly citrus flavor than lemon, but it was super crispy and delicious. We had chow mien, fried rice, and wonton soup - American style Chinese staples, right? They were all full of meat and veggies, not overly salty. My dad asked for hot mustard and she brought him regular hot dog style mustard, which was odd but have may just been a "lost in translation" thing. If I lived in San Francisco, I would go back. 

Note: cash only!
author: Sarah S.

description:
This place is literally right at the end of the Chinese New Years parade route. One of my favorite photography spots for the parade, its the end, the people in the parade are so happy to be done with the super long long walk. As I was hanging out I started to get hungry and think about going home, I looked around and found that this place scored better on yelp than all the rest. If ot for the circumstances I would have never sought out Yan's.

The place was totally packed out the door. I walked up to the window and looked at the menu then called without going inside. The place was so crowded the last thing they needed was someone else making a pick up order as the walked around taking care of the customers. I saw her pick up and answer the phone from the window. 

The place smelled great and I saw all the customers happily picking away at their full plates. 

$24 and I got 2 entree beef s, rice plate and a appetizer. I thought this was a great deal. It was so much food I actually ended up eating it for lunch a few days at work. I don't like to eat the same thing day after day but it was not bad as a leftover meal.

String Bean Beef
Chicken Cashews
Garlic Shrimp 
Egg Rolls
The Garlic Shrimp was killer. The String Bean Beef was steady and true to an Americanized beef and vegetable dish but very good. The Egg rolls were also standard. The cashew Chicken had great flavor. 

They have hot Mustard by the mustard bottle in the restaurant but do not have to go containers for it. They gave me a cup so I took a bunch. Good hot mustard.
author: Ben M.

description: Definitely a hidden gem with fantastic food. We ordered Chicken with bamboo, black mushrooms, and bamboo shoot. It was amazing, and the sauce is delicious! Everyone else in the group loved their meal. Huge fan of the dumplings, they are very flavorful. The owners are super nice, and service is quick. We have all made it official to visit every time we return to San Francisco!
author: Nikki S.

description:
The orange chicken is AMAZING, the best dish I've had at any Chinese restaurant ever, and the service is awesome, but I had a chicken noodle soup was just meh. Still, I love this restaurant and HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT.
Something to remember though is that it is CASH ONLY!!!
author: Ella H.

description:
Cash only!

Ordered the chicken chow mein to go, and it came pretty fast! Pretty good chow mein. Chicken was fresh and the noodles were thick and cooked to al dente. Quite cheap ($6-7) for a big portion. The restaurant is a bit dingy and small, but the people that run it are kind.

I noticed a lot of businessmen coming here solo to eat after work. So I'm guessing if you are wandering around the area and craving Chinese food, it won't feel too awkward to come in and eat here by yourself.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Are you kidding me???  Who are these people giving all the stars???      

I stopped in here because I was starving and it was the closest restaurant with a good Yelp rating.   I had serious reservations walking in, just because the place looked beaten up, and I didn't see a health department posting in there.  It has this ugly, depressing look to it.  

I ordered the Hunan Beef.  I don't think that was beef.   I really am wondering what that was.  It was barely edible.  It was mystery meat cooked in motor oil.   I don't know why I kept eating.  I just kept staring at the asbestos tile floor and the old lace curtains, and the chipping paint on the window, and the filth covering the vent above the door that probably has been stuck open since 1960, thinking about paying the check and getting the hell out of there.  
 
It was cheap.  Can't complain about the price.  You get what you pay for I guess.
author: J W.

description:
Food was satisfying. The chicken was crispy and flavorful. The rice was really good.
We had a side order of string beans and I must say, they were WAY TOO SALTY. 
Overall, food is good.
author: Alexia V.

description: If you have that hankering for classic take out Chinese food, then Yan's is your place. Good sized portions. It's the classic mom and pop restaurant with the standard Chinese menu recipes. Beer/wine available, including New Belgium Fat Tire. Dumplings are deep fried, instead of pan fried. CASH ONLY!
author: Kevin M.

description:
I work in the city 2 days a week, on Montgomery at Jackson.  I took the office girls to lunch at Yan's, after checking the yelp reviews.  We wanted Chinese, and this place fit the bill....more on that later.  

We each got the rice plate specials(read lunch specials).  We all got soup....and let's just say Chinese minestrone is wrong on any level.  But that was the low point. 

I got the Kung Pao Chicken, the girls got combination(chicken, shrimp, beef) in Mongolian sauce.  Holy Moly, the food was so delicious!!  Some of the best Chinese food I have ever tasted.  We also got the vegetable egg rolls and the fried dumplings(pork and scallions) and they were the best ever, seriously.  

Back to the bill: It was 29 bucks.  Id call that a steal for the financial district.   

I recommend going, or calling ahead and taking it back as the place is small and gets crowded fast.
author: Jeffrey M.

description:
We came here for some dinner as we were close to Chinatown/Little Italy. First thing we noticed about the restaurant is that it is very simple but clean. We then saw the husband and wife team running the kitchen. They were pretty cute working together while the Mr. Yan was cooking and Mrs. Yan was hosting and serving our food.

We got a dinner special with soup, rice, hunan beef and orange chicken. The food was good, but nothing out of the ordinary. The portions were pretty huge for the two of us, and prices were pretty cheap! Looking at the menu, it looks like the lunch specials are the way to go here. Next time we will have to try this place out for lunch.
author: Felicia L.

description: Lunch special here is really great value; A lot of bang for your buck. Nice little place. Though I always order for pick up. This place always hits the spot.
author: Gabriel M.

description: Excellent value Chinese food. Made fresh to order. Line round the block at lunch time. Don't be deceived by its somewhat shabby appearance...
author: Hannah B.

description: A chinese couple run the restaurant, so they serve as chef, waiter, cashier... I should have tried the general tso's chicken because there is no this dish at all in China but it turns out General Tso's is so well-known here... I had the eggplant and beef. The beef was a little weird, but its always nice to have some cheap chinese food when you are tired of sandwich, pizza, sushi...
author: Chang L.

description: I had a mission and that mission was Chinese food. I left Mr. wings and proceeded to walk out when walking down the street I noticed Yan's. I thought it may be hit or miss when walking through China Town like you may get some dog or cat so I really had my fingers crossed on it being some legit general two chicken, and I gotta tell you I was quite happy with my choice. The lady who cooked it was very nice and sweet and that came through in her dish, the chicken was cooked to perfection and hit the spot. I would come back
author: Rick S.

description:
Looking for good food in chinatown can be tough since most of the places are junk.

The wifey and I had to visit the post office to take care of some biz. After handling our ish we both were very hungry.

We walked a few streets and nothing looked good to us, so we hit up the mighty yelp for assistance.

Found this place and decided to give it a whirl.

It was an off time when we came, so the place was empty and uncle was eating his lunch.

I took a quick peek around and the place is pretty greasy like your typical american greasy spoon diner. At this point I was a bit skeptical on the food.

Checked out the menu and they had some rice plate specials.

Wifey got the General Tso's Chicken(she is embarrassing) and I got the Pepper & Salt Fish.

Egg rolls came with our meal and after my first bite I was pleasantly surprised. The inside of the egg roll was full of bright and vibrant colors. Everything was super fresh! Honestly I did not expect it to be so tasty, but it was.

Our dishes came and I was hoping it would be as great as the egg roll. Uncle Yan did not disappoint. My fish was light battered, crispy and perfectly seasoned. Damn Uncle can work that wok like a balla!

I stole a piece of the wifey's chicken and it was bomb, so I took another piece when she wasn't looking.

Overall experience was awesome and the food is so tasty. Honestly if you just walked pasted this place you would not give it a second look since its not all fancy and polished up like the other establishments in the area. But you would be missing out on a great experience.

I'll be back for sure.
author: Jerry H.
